 Notion of fast U.S. recovery falls flat at parley
 At annual meeting, economists see little chance recession will end in `09
 
 
 
The idea that the U.S. economy is going to recover in the next six months is given little credence at a gathering of top academic economists here over the weekend.
 
 A pickup sometime after June is still the Federal Reserve's quasi-official forecast. And leading institutional forecasters surveyed by the Blue Chip Economic Indicators are optimistic. 
 
 But that forecast seemed woefully out of touch to many experts who spoke at the annual meeting of the American Economics Association. 
 
 [SNIP]
 
 Despite all these efforts, the U.S. economy, hit by an oil shock, a credit crunch and the global downturn, seems to be on a steep slide. 
 
 Some argue that the recession has just begun, despite the formal ruling by the business-cycle-dating committee that it began in December 2007. 
 
 Alan Blinder, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the recession began only in mid-September when Lehman Brothers collapsed. 
 
 "We are in a horrible mess. I believe it is very young and it is going to be long and deep," he said. 
 Even in the first quarter of 2010, the economy will likely be weak enough to need macro stimulus, he said.
 
 Martin Feldstein, the prominent Harvard University economist, said there was no longer any basis for believing the recovery could start in the third quarter. 
 
 "I think we'll be lucky if by this time next year we see the economy hit the bottom and start turning up," Feldstein said. 
 
 "In terms of the level of activity, the end of 2009 is going to look lower than it is today," he said.

 YES. It absolutely DID. It was not even that uncommon (though most of the houses were more in the 250-275K range). 
 
 The loans that were being made were absolutely ludicrous. If you look at some of the "sob stories" the media has been putting up about people losing their homes it takes about 30 seconds to realize that those people never should habe HAD those loans. There was one on MSNBC the other day about a woman in California...a nurse...who had purchased 6 homes in the last 5 years with a total value of $1.47 million dollars...on a salary of $69,000 per year. She lived in one and rented all the rest with no positive cash flow. The problem came when home values started falling and rents started falling and she lost her tenants in one of the units. She had no cash reserves AT ALL so a single month with no rent payment put her out of the game for that location...then she started trying to shuffle money around and cover the shortage and put all the rest in arrears.
 
 A lot of those problems were, quite frankly, caused by the "get rich with real estate" charlatans you see on TV that advise people to buy homes, rent them for a marginal cash flow, and then refinance them every 4 years when the value increases. They actually call it "harvesting equity" and compare it to harvesting a crop. It works relatively well as long as property values are increasing and interest rates remain low. As soon as property values start decreasing or interest rates increase, which increases your debt service costs, or you hit an economic slowdown and you have to increase rents, you have a BIG PROBLEM.
 
 Overall the real problem in the housing market, what allowed the bubble to get so big, was that everybody became a mini real estate speculator. I have talked to DOZENS of real estate agents and not a single one of htem can recall making even one sale in the run up to the bubble bursting that was not at least partially speculative in nature. Even people who planned to live in the house were trying to get the biggest house they possibly could, even if it was more than they could actually afford, on the logic that the value WOULD increase and it would all be OK in the long run. 
 
 That is INSANE. The strategy the nurse I cited above is not necessarily a bad one, but it is an EXTREMELY risky one. I very literally used it myself in the run up. I bought 23 houses in 2 different college towns and a "corporate" neighborhood (right next to the sprint campus in Kansas City) I rented them at zero cash flow for 3-5 years (depending on the purchase date) and then when we got to the point that cracks were beginnign to appear in the markets I dumped them all. Most of them had increased in value by 40-60%. I did not finance them with a mortgage, I took a cash loan and used a bunch of junk MBS paper that I was holding as cash collateral. The bonds paid 8.45%, but the loan only cost me 4.2% (because I posted a cash equivalent collateral). So, I still made money on the bonds (4.25%).
 
 The difference is that I made that investment because I understood how the market works and knew what to watch for. The nurse made it because she ordered a "how to get rich in RE" program from an infomercial for $39 that explained how to buy and get it financed, but did not mention that it was an incredibly risky strategy and you had to know when to get the hell out. 
 
 Chester would argue that the nurse above somehow got screwed and the lender should not have made the loan or should not have been ABLE to make the loan. Frankly, I think he is DEAD wrong. I have not seen a SINGLE case where the people who took a mortgage did not understand the consequences of taking it. People who took the exploding arms KNEW that their rate would shoot through the roof along with their payments, they just thought they would either be able to refinance first or that they would be able to sell the house off and make a bunch of money.
 
 Where people got into trouble is that they did not understand how to asses the risk they were taking or did not bother at all because they were optimistic that everything would be OK. It is the bankers job to asses overall risk. IT is the borrowers job to asses personal risk. What happens if you cant refi? What happens if you dotn get that promotion you were counting on? What happens if you lose your job? Those are the kind of thing the BORROWER has to consider, not the lender. The lender pretty much has to take the borrowers word for it.

 You'd be better off just not seizing anymore wages from the person going bankrupt and have them foreclose, have no home, and rent somewhere based on the salary they have. If they are unemployed and have no income than $2000 isn't going to change whether or not they can pay rent.

 
 I am not necessarily opposed to the idea of the taxpayer picking up the tab on it if it keeps families from ending up in the street. The problem is that we have programs in place to help pay rents for those who need it, but often people are unable to participate because they cannot afford the move in cost (security deposit, etc...). 
 
 I would support something like that for the same reason I am a strong supporter of the food stamps problem. It is cheaper to feed people than to fight them. You put enough families out on the street and eventually they react. 
 

 This might not work either because banks would just create a subsidiary that they would "sell" the house to that would treat them as investment properties much like you see with some people on a small scale now (buying up homes and fixing them up and selling them later). So nothing gets accomplished other than a circumvent of the law. The banks end up paying for sitting on them in the long run thanks to property taxes. 

 
 That is pretty obviously not enough incentive for these banks to aggressively move these properties or they would be doing it now. Instead they are letting them sit and become a blight on the neighborhood. 
 
 
I'd be ok with making a law that had property taxes double or triple on companies or persons that own 3 or more vacant homes...or something like that. This would accomplish the same thing you are trying to accomplish.
 
 I like the property tax idea :) If you are paying $2,000 on taxes for a home and all of a sudden you owe another $4,000 a year than sitting on it is really killing you.

 
 Denver tried that and ended up fighting enough "equal protection' lawsuits that they eventually gave up on the plan. 
 
 Ultimately I think what will end up happening is a return to early american property values. Up until the 1920's you could literally move into an abandoned house and as soon as you could show residency, you could file a claim for a deed and it became yours. That is a DRASTIC departure from todays understanding of property rights, but it is actually a more efficient method of making land and property productive than the market is. Our liberal views on land rights is one of the things that allowed America to grow as quickly as it did in the early years....you either used it or somebody who WOULD use it did. The saying "possession is 9/10ths of the law" is a saying that goes back to land rights in the 19th century in America. If the other guy had a deed, but you had a crop in, it was yours and screw his deed. That allowed us to get HUGE amounts of land into production very quickly. 
 
 Letting houses rot and land sit idle because banks are not really equipped to get them on the market is an ENORMOUS waste of wealth. We are not just talking MONEY here. Destroying money is no big deal. We are talking the actual destruction of WEALTH, which is an unforgivable sin.

 He was right....it was INSANELY risky, but I assessed the risk, figured out what the worst case scenario would be, and in my opinion felt the risk was worth taking.
 
 If accountants ran everything we would all have our money in CDs at 2.75%...crappy yield, but NO risk. 
 
 The point is that risk is a natural part of business. It is up to YOU to asses the risk you are taking...not anybody else...and what may be a perfectly acceptable risk for you is a TERRIBLE idea for somebody else. That deal was a good one for me and worth the risk...but then if I had lost on it, it would not have wiped me out and I could afford to take the hit. For somebody with $10,000 in savings to take it all and do the same thing, and put their house up as collateral would NOT have been a good idea because a loss would have destroyed them.
 
 Circumstances for different for different people. There is no one size that fits all, which is why everybody must do their OWN risk analysis.
